This game just isnt for me.

first of all, I get the feeling that the devs were not given enough time to make this game feature-complete and refine some aspects of the game.

I will go into detail with things I didnt like and there might be some mild spoilers ahead. You've been warned.

_______________________________________________________________________

Tutorial:
basically useless.
I had to figure stuff out myself.
This would have been fine, but if you put a tutorial in a game, please try to make it actually helpful.

I strongly dislike the combat in this game:
the AI is dumb af. Either they are running away from you, or they will just headon fight you to the death.
The bossfights are very annoying and take ages, because they are bulletsponges, even with high skills and the best weapons. (possibly several ingame days).
Of cause you could call this "challanging", but its clearly not the way I would want it from a game.

Ressources:
I dont understand a lot of the logic behind the ressources in this game.
The only fully grown trees you can cut down are palms. Other big trees you simply can not interact with, wich does not make sense to me.
Trees will not regrow, which is fine, bot neither will flowers you picked and I dont get why this is, because you can clearly plant them in a farmplot. Just so you actually have to use the farmplot?
big BS if you ask me, especially because the remnants of those flowers will stay there for every, like a grave saying "this used to be the home of an innocent flower UNTIL A BARBARIC MONSTER CAME AND RIPPED THEM OUT!"
Another thing I dont get is, why cou can not pick up certain items. I can carrie a fully loaded chest with 5 logs in them. why cant I carry one empty oil-barrel? Yes, you can drag them, but not put them in your inventory.

Story:
If you can call it that... At some point you have to fill up a container with food, but this container does not give a single soletary flying f*** abut what food you give them or if it is even prepared and that just doesnt make any sense to me.

Building a raft:
This could not be more static.
I understand that this is not meant to be a game where you only leave your raft to gather ressources, since this is not "raft"(the game), but it is not very fullfilling to see how limited the options are when it comes to building yoiur raft and especially to build stuff on top of it.
Building doesnt feel very polished either.

Game-map:
you get a map even before you start the game, but I dont understand why there is no option to have a map in game. The only orientation you get are the ocean current, the sun and a compass. Not what I would expect from a game like this. but thats just me being salty I guess.

I really liked the concept of the game, but the way it was made in the end, completely destroyed the fun for me and I got more frustrated with every day that passed.
I'll rather go back to raft and put a couple of hundred hours into that.

If you made it to this point, thank you for taking the time to actually read it.
I hope it helps to figure out if this game is for you.

161933488.review:
If you ever watched the movie Cast Away (2000, with Tom Hanks) and said to yourself something like "being stranded on a desert island and having to save myself would be interesting" this might be for you. The game pays some fun homage to the film but maintains it's own story and concept.

The single player story mode is open world survival in a classic form with no online components, just you, the ocean, the elements and survival, which I enjoyed. Some liberties are taken and this is not brutally realistic, but still challenging.

Game play can be a little buggy, certain mechanics get messed up during save states, and I was able to accidentally soft-lock the game once, but since this game does not auto-save I just crashed it and started from my previous save.

It took me 49 hours and 48 minutes to complete the story and collect all of the achievements, so probably not for those looking for a quick 100%er. One-shot-ing "Magnets" and "Gotta Craft'em All" was pretty challenging and exhausting.

158988995.review:
A very brutal game with almost no documentation. It will kill you a hundred times, and never tell you why.

For example, consider the Poisoned condition. How does it happen? How dangerous is it? How can you fix it? You should be able to figure out the answers to these questions through gameplay (or the manual, if the game had one), but the only actual way to figure them out is by reading spoiler material.

The controls are very controller-centric. However, you sometimes need precision aiming, which is a pain with a controller, so I use a mouse and keyboard. But things like radial selection menus are a pain with keyboard and mouse. Some of the keyboard controls can't be reassigned, which is a pain if you aren't using a US qwerty keyboard layout.

The crafting is balanced in such a way as to make everything in the game non-renewable. This is by design. I understand it might be appealing to some, but it is not appealing to me.

I feel, as the game stands, there isn't enough danger. I am fully aware that it is early days, but i'm also aware they're open to suggestions. I recommend the game as it stands, if you are happy funding development for a game that has SO MUCH potential, and a few solid hours of enjoyment in it's current state.

Things i'd personally like to see:

-Less sharks (they should be terrifying when encountered, dangerous depending on the species, and you shouldn't be able to swim as fast as them and kill them with your pocket knife. Get rid of that stupid music too, a shark attack should be unexpected, this isn't Jaws.)
-You should be able to break your raft if you hit it with a sharp object... if you're stupid enough to attack your boat, you deserve to die.
-More island variations: It feels that every island is 'roughly' the same size, and they're all spread out at equal distances... perhaps a few islands linked together, maybe a big island with cliffs (give an element to exploring the land as well as the sea).
-Seabirds, with eggs that you can steal to eat!
-Saltwater crocs (danger in the shallows and on the land)
-A character screen: Being able to equip items would make this game so much fun, like piecing together some torn rags to help shelter your skin from the sun, or making a crappy little hat to help prevent dehydration. Also when you get the diving gear, it gives a chance to equip it/unequip it...
-Blood: Having 'blood' to monitor might be interesting too, as cutting yourself could lead to unwanted attention in the water... you should be able to fashion bandages to stop the bleeding, giving a new element to your survival.
-Sharp coral in the shallows (in some places). This will make you have to be careful where you come ashore, as you could cut your feet.
-Clams
-illness: I want the fact I don't have a shelter, and it pisses it down with rain, to kill me. Or if I cut myself and don't bother rubbing that one special plant on the wound, the infection to kill me.
-Variations on underwater wrecks (big/small boats, war planes, a lost town which was swallowed by the ocean!?)
-Rocks pools (with the crabs in them... instead of just randomly on the beach at 'crab nests') I hate the fact the crabs are so easy to find... this game needs to be about scavenging and surviving, not just sitting and cooking crab after crab.
-All trees should be destroyable for wood.
-Torches (as in a fire torch)
-The ability to build bigger better rafts! Most the time you're traveling, until you find that one 'BIG' island, with the resources to survive, you need to travel, so why not be able to pimp your ride? A wind sail from palm leaves or a rudder from wood. Places to store supplies on rafts.
-Bee/wasp nests (you need a torch/smoke to obtain the honey safely)
-Scorpions/Snakes/Spiders: You'll have to be careful where you tread (also going back to clothing, you can fashion shoes from coconut husks to protect your feet)
***Fires should be maintainable instead of having to make a new one each time (ALREADY IN)
-More interactive surroundings: For example, I think bigger stones should be movable, so you can stack them to make walls. The starfish should be movable too,  so if you want to pick one up and throw it, why not?
-More building options: I'm tired of this 'minecraft' style building option all games give... The shelters in the game look more like something the sims would offer. I want to see actual shelters you can build, cut two trees down, place them over the top of  a boat on its side for supports, lash together palm leaves for a roof - bam a shelter. For example, making the rope a 'pin' object would be interesting, so you can 'pin' two items together, and create your own shelters this way.
-Schools of fish
-Coral reefs
-Great white sharks remade (bigger for one thing... and at the moment they look like they're from pixar films)
-Cave systems to explore (both on islands and in the water)
-Berries (eat them at your own risk, some are poisonous)
-A diary
-More options for various items (improved camp fires? for example, a camp fire 'pit' (requires stones, shovel and more wood). 

Basically, to sum it up, I feel the game lacks the survival and creativity it potentially has. I find myself sitting on a beach, cutting down a few trees, making a minecraft shelter and eating crabs for hours until I die (of boredom). 
I want to be creating rain catchers, building a tropical paradise (to some extent... when man has nothing, everything is a luxary) better shelters, exploring the ocean with dangers everywhere, having to build new rafts because I stupidly hit my first one with an axe to see if it would break it, fighting off wild animals left right and center.

14212460.review:
Stranded launched with a major bug in the raft. That was Friday. On Tuesday, the devs showed up with the hotfix. Not only did they fix the raft, they improved and patched a whole laundry list of stuff. And added whales! Attentive and competent.

Why is this the first thing I'm telling you about Stranded? Because it's Early Access, which means "Dev Attentiveness" is everything. I couldn't even think of reviewing this game until we'd seen them in action, at least once. Now we have seen them in action, and it was quite impressive. Not unlike the game itself.

Stranded is a beautiful little shipwrecked simulator. It's very basic right now, but what's here is all well done, and they've got some clever ideas. 

Crafting, for example, forgoes the usual subscreen, and revolves around you piling up the materials on the ground, in physical proximity. Want a spit to cook by your campfire? You can't just build a spit and place it. You can only do it if the materials are right there, next to the fire. It's tactile. It's vaguely clunky, but it's very organic. You feel like you're really standing there, trying, like Robinson Crusoe, to forge a life out of sticks and palm fronds.

The islands are another interesting design choice. They're very small, and fairly anemic. Sticks and rocks and Yuca twine. The vast majority of the game is actually out there, under the water, with the sharks. Old shipwrecks and reefs and lost containers and such. The sharks are scary. If you're from the ocean/shark phobia branch of unreasonable fears, like myself, you will find the sharks, and their obligatory accompanying obo (edit: piano) music, genuinely terrifying. The sum of all this is that you're in a hyper relaxing tropical island coconut eating game, but if you want to get anything done, you have to get in the water, and play an intensely stressful horror game with roaming bull and tiger sharks. Neat stuff.

It's all gorgeous, as the screenshots suggest. You'd never know the title was indie, or early access, by glancing at it. I thought the whales were good news, not just because whales are cool, but because it shows us that these devs are invested in their wildlife. Anyone who's played The Forest can attest to how much a robust ecosystem adds to a setting like this one.

At this point, I only have one major complaint, and that's the ocean. The ocean is too calm. It's beautiful, and the part where it has depth and you're constantly trying to figure out what's below you is amazing and immersive, but you're way off in the pacific someplace, and sea is calm as can be. Even the Gulf Coast of Florida has itty bitty waves. After the great rolling oceans of Assassin's Creed Black Flag, and the slightly less mountainous but still very rolling seas of this game's own indie cousin, Salt, the planar ocean of Stranded is like a dead rat in the punch bowl. In most games, it wouldn't matter so much, but the ocean is the star of Stranded; it rarely, if ever, leaves center stage. The fact that it is lifeless as a dish towel never stops feeling wrong.

Aside from that, I can't think of anything to complain about. Had they not just introduced the whales, I would worry about the sharks being too large and scary, and wish for a wider variety of sharks, including all the relatively pleasant ones that fill the real oceans. (Back in the 70s, sharks hired Steven Spielberg as a PR guy, and it was kind of a disaster. It would be nice if Stranded helped them dig out of that, a little.) But, whales. There's probably all kinds of critters coming. If there are still no nice sharks a year from now, I'll come edit this paragraph.

TL;DR - Great start on a shipwrecked simulator. Devs seem to care. All is beautiful. Oceans too flat. Sharks need friends. Safe to buy.

14140430.review:
Date of writing this review: 24/1/15, just one day after it has come out so obviously if you are reading this att a later date, my criticisms may have been addressed (in which I am almost sure they will be). I would like to also state, that at the time of writing this review, I only have 3 hours of playtime - and so this is more of a first impression.

[h1]The Positives[/h1]
Unique game idea. Cast away being one of my favourite movies, it feels great to relive Tom Hank's struggle! And yes, it is possible to get Wilson!

This game is visually [i]gorgeous.[/i] The sunrises and sunsets look real. The colours spread across the whole sky, and it is absolutely breathtaking. These graphics add a sense of immersion to which I have not experienced in many other games before. 
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=380387079
[i]A sunrise in Stranded Deep[/i]

The game is realistic (at times). Chipping away at a tree, then finally seeing it fall down is truley incredible, and in my opinion, much better than the Forest. This is as the tree doesn't simply split into pieces like it does in the Forest, but rather you must further cut the tree into logs, and then sticks. Again, this adds another sense of immersion to the game, making the player feel as though they are in fact stranded.

[h1]The Negatives[/h1]
The game feels a bit too easy, and repetitive. You can go without eating or drinking for 2-3 days without consequence, even so, there are millions of coconuts lying around which you can drink, and 3 or 4 potato plants in each island in which regrow after a day. It is near impossible to die from hunger or thirst. I would have liked to have seen them focus more on making actual survival hard, rather than worrying about that shark (that in my opinion adds nothing to the game).

Currently, there is no end game (although they have stated that it is in the works). This wouldn't be a problem at all if actual survival was challenging. 

Base building is useless. So what you build a 3x3 home? You just have to move to another island at somepoint anyway. Would be better if they focused more on being able to build an awesome raft, as building a home is useless, and being mobile is key. 

[h1]The Verdict[/h1]
If survival is your type of game, and/or you loved the movie Cast Away, I would definitely reccomend purchasing this game as is, now! It has so much potential, and I hope to see so many more features in the future. All up, I will give it a 7/10 in it's current state, however it definitely has the potential to be the best survival game on the market.

Thank you for reading, should you have a question, feel free to comment, or even add me. I will respond ASAP. This being me second proper review, could you guys also leave me some constructive criticism, thanks guys!

14127404.review:
First Impressions (Will update with more experience later)

Visually this game is breathtaking, Being that you're around water so often I can't help but abosolutely love the look of it, when you look into it from your raft you can see quite deep which feels very realistic when you're swimming total blackness is common and  a very scary feeling. The sense of exploration and adventure in this title is amazing, I often found myself needing a little courage before jumping in the water out of fear of tiger sharks or any of the other predators that lie about. Attention to detail is quite nice to, I killed a crab with my knife and then ate it to which I took damage (I'm assuming either by the shell or because it's raw) I love that this game doesn't hold you hand, it throws you on an island and you have to survive with expirementation. It gives you just enough helpful supplies to make your stay not impossible but not enough to make it easy. Even with only a couple hours of gameplay I can honestly say this game has much potential, I'm not saying it's good yet, that takes more time. But I am enjoying it.

EDIT

Crafting: Ok I tested out some of the crafting aspects now and I can say at the start I absolutely hated the whole drop mechanism for crafting. Basically you bundle everything on the ground and then use items and tools to craft different things from the ground. After a while I really took a liking to it however, I'm not sure why but it feels realistic. If I was on a island I can't help but believe I would start gathering and sort my materials on the ground until I decided what I should do with them, although this isn't huge I really enjoyed this method of crafting. I also like that a foundation can be either a floor or a raft, let's face it, they're not much different just a bunch of sticks tied together, really great idea making both into one craftable item. Overall I really like the Crafting system.

Fishing: I only fished for a short while but visually it's great, the fish stick to your spear and wiggle around a bit, feels very realistic (not that I go around stabbing fish).

EDIT

Sharks: Shark AI seems very decent. I decided to go out and try to fight one off and it was a very close fight, the movement is what I immediately noticed, they move like a natural predator where they will sneak in for a bite then go into the depths and come back in for another attack. They're also extremely weary of confrontation so if you start swining a knife at it it will swim away. Very nice could definitely be a bit more difficult though.

Bugs: Currently theres a very annoying bug that will make you lose your raft in the middle of the ocean, this happened to me twice in a row where I had no choice but to swim to the island. 

Again will update with more info when I see it necessary.

68127502.review:
TL DR: PC players got kinda scammed by devs, their funding was put into finished console ports, while the original PC SD doesn't seem to escape the clusterfunk of a five years Early Access quite soon.

Yeah, no. I had a lot of patience with this game, but now, it's completely gone.

I follow the development of this game since its EA release back in 2015. Then they were planning to get this out of Early Access in the same year. It has been five years in which core mechanics were changed, added, removed and reworked multiple times which added to the product that we have today. Communication by the devs (two people btw) with us (us meaning the PC community) grew bad in the last months, updates began to shift from one content patch per month to "maybe one patch in three months and wait this new update is actually only bringing already existing content from the experimental branch to the stable one". 

Btw this game is broken and I'm not only referring to its bugs, I also heard that a lot of people can not run this game and also this game is freakin' boring. 

So Stranded Deep just released on Xbox One and PS4 after a one-year-lasting hiatus with Beam Team Games trying to reclaim the publishing rights from Telltale Publishing, after they got broke shortly after the announcement of their collaboration. And yes, on consoles Stranded Deep is released, despite still being Early Access on Steam. How does this work?

So basically you may realized, that SD on consoles has a full endgame which is still missing on PC. But that does'nt mean that the console version has just more features than the PC one. In fact the PS4/XBoxOne version runs on an old build, that e.g. still has the item "tarp", which was removed on PC like many months ago. 

The devs already said that they want to add missing features from PC to console and vice versa. But no one knows WHEN exactly we PC-players can expect to get out of EA.

I should also mention that the few patches we PCers got in the last months are pretty scummy. Some months ago, we got new animals like a giant crab. This crab was not made by the devs however, instead they bought a license for it: https://sketchfab.com/3d-models/giant-crab-animations-7a914f49409c4e37b7da8d6b12b94a2c 
Of course that's not illegal, but it shows me that they swapped their priorities.

The most requested feature since 2015 is clearly coop-mode, which also appears on their roadmap. So some time back we got coop, however it happens to be splitscreen coop, which nobody wanted. Like look at a game like The Forest, it got coop very quick and I don't think anyone there misses an option for splitscreen coop. According to the devs online coop is "on their radar", but I guess PC release also seems to be "on their radar" for like four years.

If you look on their Twitter you can see that the devs got pretty active in the minute this game came out for consoles. Small streamers seem to get sponsored and there is a lot of communication with the consolers e.g. about upcoming hotfixes and such. However there is no official statement about the PC release, if you want to get an official word on that of a dev, you have to dig yourself into the Steam Forums. Actually they seem to be surprised by getting some negative critique from people who feel scammed by them. And this is what it is.

If I buy a game in EA I expect to give money to the devs so that they can fund the game I CAN PLAY with the money. Instead they used it to develop a finished console version. Now some randoms that never supported this game before can play endgame content BEFORE the real funders of the game.

Anyway I expect that in sometime (maybe a month, maybe a year who knows) we get a patch that adds the endgame from consoles, the unlimited world (one of the features that was in this game already years ago, but got removed because idk) and then the devs declear this game as "done". But then SD will still be nothing more than a neat cheap survival game that gets boring really quick and gets crushed by games like The Forest or Green Hell (approximately same price for well better games with online coop and such).

Thank you, Beam Team.

14248982.review:
After about an hour of sitting on an island wishing I hadn't accidentally used all of my rocks to craft tools, I finally resigned myself to my plan of paddling out to a distant island to see if I could gather up some more. I paddled for ages and was incredibly excited to see the new shore. It was a small island with a wrecked ship on both it's east and west sides. After gathering a sizable pile of rocks to take back to my sad little home island, I decided to pull out my knife and explore the shipwrecks.

As I swam down into the tiny fishing trawler, I wondered how long I could hold my breath. Long enough to discover a hatchet stuffed away in a locker, and a fuel tank stored in the ship's console, and a spare lighter stored away in a toolbox. I excitedly tossed my treasure on the ground by my raft, eager to see what was located in the other ship.

This ship was much larger, maybe a crabbing boat or something. It had at least two decks. I couldn't discover the hidden gems in this thing. Oooh! Is that another hatchet? Yes! Awesome! Whoa, a machete?! Sweet, I should probably go up for air. Alright, air is sufficient. Let's go back down. Wait...what is this music? There hasn't been any music before...this sounds...ominous. Please tell me there aren't sharks in this game...OH CRAP, THAT'S A SHARK. SWIM DAMN YOU, SWIM.

After escaping what was certain death, I went back to my raft and settled on what to take back home with me. The rocks, the fuel tank, and my beautiful new machete. The rest, I left on the beach for easy access if I ever decided to grow a pair and finish exploring that boat.

As I began paddling back to my island, I reflected on my performance while I experienced extreme fear after spotting the shark, quite happy with myself. I escaped the wrath of a frightening creature while stupidly swimming around in his home turf. I can outperform sharks, man. I'm awesome.

It was at this moment of smug satisfaction that I heard the ominous music again and immediately reverted back to fear mode, and looked around my raft in a panic, trying to spot my tormentor. Suddenly my raft was violently pushed by something below me. I flipped out and started mashing buttons in an effort to pull out my new, prized machete treasure. In my panic, I managed to press Q instead, which resulted in my hurling the tiny plastic paddle I was using to transport myself home directly at the shark's head.

Realizing I was now stranded in a raft with no way to paddle back home, being circled by a large sea creature with enough teeth to completely ruin my day, I quit the game and decided to sit in bed for awhile wrapped in a cozy, warm blanket.

8/10 will most definitely play again.

119788333.review:
I have almost 50 hours now. This game has some potential but the negatives far outweigh what could have been a good game. Where should I start...

Building mechanics make absolutely no sense. There is literally no gameplay difference between building a twig shack and a brick fortress (apart from costing you significantly more). Not only that, there is zero incentive to build *anything* at all, as buildings won't protect you against rain, wind and cold - they simply do not exist in the game apart from visuals/sound fx. Animals pass through walls so no point in building a base, apart from trying to RP which in this game gets boring fast.

Same applies for rafts - different materials used to build the raft hardly matter at all. Do not read what is written as information - I can barely notice any difference in the way the raft behaves if it is built using different materials. So why you need level 4 crafting to build the barrel raft when a twig one can do as much is beyond me. Or, why do you need to put an expensive brick floor on top of the raft base when you can go around with planks of wood. Also, bricks as a raft floor - are you serious? And if you are trying to haul barrels - no matter how big your raft is, you can barely load a barrel or maybe two (if you are lucky) before the raft starts sinking or going awry in circles. In my game, I managed to transport a couple of barrels using the starting dinghy - so the only reason to build a raft is speed and to be able to haul crates on a shelf. You cannot even build some sort of a half-wall to prevent stuff like tyres and barrels from falling off.

Resources are also bland and far not enough. Sure, the basics are there but oh my god, the crafting menu and UI is abhorrent. It is all over the place, you cannot favourite certain items, only pin what you will need to gather before crafting it but not actually craft it unless you go again through all the menus. Horrible. Variety is bad, soon you will end up with dozens of label makers, compasses, underwater torches, vehicle parts which are fairly useless if you already have 1 of each (or a few in the case of vehicle parts). Inventory is disorganised and honestly this is the only game where your empty hands count as a part of the inventory. On top of that, you can easily stack everything in boxes and then pick the boxes with the items inside, game seems to not care. But as soon as you have all the slots occupied and have - lets say 2 axes, you suddenly cannot equip neither as the game tries to split them into two slots - without any logic whatsoever. A total mess.

AI is also incredibly poor for a game this new. Animals get stuck on everything, combat is incredibly clunky and lacking anything interesting. Sound effects are lacking, soundtrack is nice but very short and easily becomes very repetitive as everything else in this game. And why the hell do the tiger sharks make a growling noise when biting?! They are sharks, not tigers. What's next? Horse flies that neigh??? Graphics can either be good or bad - some aspects are nice but they still feel very outdated.

All that being said, there are some good features. Procedural generation offers some replayability so long you are not incredibly bored by the time you finished the game the first time. The map itself is not infinite as the devs would like you believe, rather it consists of a few dozens small islets but scattered around differently every game. 

There is also an option to create custom maps and islands but the map editor is so frustratingly terrible to navigate, this options is borderline useless. Trying to build a simple island, raise tool actually lowers the land, the other tools are buggy as hell, did not stay there for more than 5 minutes, it was THAT buggy.

Overall, you will like the idea of this game, but not the game itself. There are way better games in the same category out there.
If you are still willing to buy, do not buy at full price. This game does not deserve to be priced that high.

EDIT: typos.

38148640.review:
Review December 2017 />

“We don't want to work on Stranded Deep forever. If all goes well, we're hoping to have it completed by the end of 2015."

Coming back after a year since I played, I'm a little disappointed to see it is still EA, as this game has a huge potential. 
There is a lot to improve, and the devs are certainly taking their time, or simply have given up on the game. 
What the game could improve on:

- Bigger, more interesting islands. For instance it would be cool with a beach cove or small caves (with clay deposits). Volcano islands or underwater volcanoes. 

- More wildlife. Could be simple thing as poisonous spiders, scorpions, chameleons, mosquito swarms - or bigger ones like iguanas. Including underwater life like whale sharks, groups of dolphins spotted in the distance etc. 

- Less coconuts - More varied sources of food. Bananas. Berries (including poisonous ones), papayas, other exotic fruits etc. In its current state it is too easy going from island to island and replenish on food and water from coconuts.

- Different sound effects. Example: Hacking trees or paddling in the life raft should have 3 or 4 sound effects each. Yeah, it does actually make a difference when you do it a whole day.

- Cutting out the cheesy voice lines saying "Eww, gross" when skinning a crab and trying to survive. Add more random dialogue that could occur from time to time, like how he's hoping he will be rescued soon, how he's curious about the new island he's arriving on, how he hopes there are no sharks around when he goes for that shipwreck etc.

- Random drops; Traces of previous ancestors, history relics, ancient ruins, message in a bottle etc. Maybe some personal belongings from the people on the plane. 

- Less frequent shark encounters. So that you actually have the guts to take a swim but will get more freaked out when you meet a shark. Not having them swimming around your island constantly. 

- More objectives/ quests: Would be awesome finding a treasure map / key belonging to another island (in the same island group) that you have to seek out. Maybe a bigger island, having to fight a panther boss or something.



They have indeed made a few new improvements, like adding storms with huge waves. But all in all the process is too slow. I'm sure if they pick up the pace and make some new features and more varied content, this will be a 50+ hour game (add multiplayer on top and it's 150+), rather than its current state where you get more or less bored after 10 hours. 

Don't get me wrong, it's not a bad game, and with great graphics. I'm just disappointed seeing the progress with just a couple new features since I last played, over a year ago. For me personally, there was no replay value, which I usually have with most games. If it was a FULL release when buying, it would be something different. But I bought it in EA, thinking a lot more content would come. 

I'm not at all expecting them to make all the ideas above, but it's just some suggestions to make the game less repetitive. I hope they continue in the right direction and will be more than happy to change this review later on. Like mentioned this game has potential, and could possibly be among the best games in 2018 if done right!

They have done some things since I last played this four years ago! More wildlife, more objects to make, I can recommend this now. Though they could work on the audio and turn down the shark frequency (constantly being followed by my new pet, hammerhead fella :)

69900803.review:
I bought this based on Steam's recommendation, because I played a lot of Subnautica and The Forest (both of which are amazing games).

Stranded Deep is ok, but not quite as good as the two previously mentioned survival games.  There's just some stuff in the game that doesn't seem very well thought out.

The reward structure for exploration is just not refined enough.  The basics of survival are easy to take care of, after a day or two in game you should have food and water completely situated.  After that the real progress comes from sailing to other islands and diving in shipwrecks.

Sailing to other islands is mostly fine, but your limited inventory space makes it really start to wear on you as you slowly move resources 10-20 at a time back and forth to your main island.  This can be slightly helped by carrying a few storage containers on your raft, but the storage containers aren't very large and they also have a habit of sliding off or flying into the middle of the ocean.  The game would be GREATLY improved if you could build or connect storage directly to the raft.

The other exploration is diving, which was a frightful experience at the start because there are a LOT of sharks in the ocean.  Once I got over the fear of the sharks though, I realized that they are actually kind of derpy.  They don't do a terribly good job at killing you, and tend to just harmlessly swim straight through you or completely miss you unless you stand perfectly still.  But it's all kind of a wasted effort because 90% of the shipwrecks are just full of worthless flashlights.  I wish the sharks were less common and more impactful, because they're mostly just an annoying way to spend throwing spears at the moment.

There are some end game bosses that I can't manage to find in my currently game, but I did watch some videos of other people killing them and they seem to suffer from a health pool problem.  With the limited inventory space, you can only carry so many spears at once, and it looks like the bosses have WAY too much health for the amount that you can carry.  The videos I watched had people diving into the ocean just to try and pull their thrown spears out of the boss to reuse them because they ran out.

The building elements could also use a lot of polishing up.  I built some shelves in game only to find that they didn't actually work, they were just kind of one solid collision block, so I can leave a handful of items hovering a foot above the shelf, but I can't put items on an individual shelf.  It would be nice to have a few cosmetic items thrown into the sunken ships just to make those more interesting.

And the final gripe I have with the game is that there are finite resources.  I found myself, for the first time in any survival game, starved of rocks.  The only resource that seems to grow back are the leaves that you can use for fires and to make rope.  There seems to be enough resources in the game to get you through, but it's just kind of unnecessary to make me sail 6 miles just to find a stick.

All in all, it's a competent game, with a few rough edges that will hopefully get smoothed out in the future.  I can recommend it because it's a decent way to spend 10-20 hours, but it's not as good as The Forest or Subnautica, so definitely play those games first.

55225530.review:
Stranded Deep starts off great, its early game is fun, immersive, with lots to do. Though once it hits mid to late game, it becomes very repetitive. It's ending is also one of the worst out there.

The good:
*Very fun at the start of the game
*World is immersive at the start
*Lots of fun things to do at the start
*Sharks in this game specifically add a great horror element that I have never seen in another game that I have played
*Shark AI for the Tiger Sharks and Great Whites is really good
*Graphics are quite noice

The bad:
*Mid to late game is the same thing over and over, very repetitive. Collecting clay, dealing with creatures the same way, travelling long distances... the same way
*Random World Generator causes too much meshing with wrecks, making many non accessible or causing the player to get stuck
*Sharks, when moving fast, have more animations. Looks like they are moving in 15 fps, which breaks immersion
*Shark AI for Goblin and Hammerhead Sharks is annoying, they are too rapid
*There is no difference to building out of clay vs building out of sticks or planks, only visual differences, no reward for making stronger buildings
*Hurricanes/storms are annoying, they pose no threat, lightning creates unpleasant flashes
*Hard mode is annoying as it increase water consumption to insane levels
*Nights are too long, day is too short, underwater visibility is too limited with a in game 5 hour window to be able to see well
*No diving/swimming equipment, no fins, snorkel, goggles, armor, etc
*Collecting clay is tedious and boring after awhile, mining pick the whole game
*The games ending needs improvement
*No fast travel, it needs it because travelling across the map is boring and takes a long time
*Respawning snakes, crabs and large boars will knock your stuff around on the island, and you don't know when they have respawned, they often get you while you're in the middle of something.

How the game could improve:
*Add a map
*Add more story elements, unique elements about each island, things to break up the grind
*Add upgrades for equipment and buildings to improve their use
*Add water tanks for collecting water, water filtration, water purification, gutters for collecting water, water tank storage for rafts
*Make a polished world as the main world, and use Random World Generators for everything else. The main world could be polished, bug free, no meshing, add extra story elements, larger land masses, other deceased survivors and their stories
*More upgrades for rafts, better rudders for turning, better engines for faster movement, better storage system, compass holder, etc
*Essential storage for the raft that is visual and you can see how many you have without having to open every storage box. It could hold food, water, fuel, medical items, fuel etc
*Add automated notes of what the player has done on an island
*Add fast travel for islands you've discovered or add a marker the player can make and place so they can.

14505887.review:
I really enjoy this game, it's well made and definitely worth $15 even in it's current state. Here's a breakdown of gameplay, graphics, environment, crafting, bugs, and ultimately - why I would recommend this game.

[b]Gameplay:[/b]

-Pretty fun to explore shipwrecks and find stuff
-Made a motorized raft (which totally kicks ass)
-Conquered multiple islands for my own greedy needs
-Built a fortress with a lookout tower and used binoculars to spot sharks
-Still haven't found my good friend Wolly
-Murdered crabs and ate them in front of their friends
-Drank then ate numerous coconuts
-Palm trees are now extinct

Gameplay is great, crafting system is really unique and I like it, it seems realistic, like you're actually putting stuff together instead of some wizardry where walls and foundations just appear. Although at this point there's not much to do, this game has really good potential (I'll elaborate more on this at the end).

[b]Graphics:[/b]

This game is very nice looking, and has a really nice feel of realism to it. The only thing I'd want more with the graphics is better antialiasing, a fix for the weird lines you can see in the distance separating the areas of water, and further render distance.

[b]Environment:[/b]

The environment is very nice, there are plenty of sea animals and dangers. Sharks, whales, crabs, many types of fish, and more to come in the future. The islands are all pretty standard and have numerous palm trees, rocks, and a few yucca plants for lashings (rope). My favorite part about the environment is the water and shipwrecks. The water is awesome and it really feels real when you're swimming around exploring. The shipwrecks are interesting to explore and often have very useful loot like buckets (which you fill with seawater then boil to make it drinkable), parts to make an engine for your raft, and other useful items like flashlights and bandages.

[b]Crafting:[/b]

I love the crafting system in this game. I've never seen anything like it before. Instead of having to combine recipes through a crafting menu, you actually put the stuff together on the ground, hold left click, and select the item you want to make. To make tools you hold anything, but to build foundations, walls, and other building materials, you need to be holding a hammer. The crafting is very well done, no complaints about it.

[b]Bugs:[/b]

This is the least buggy early access game I've ever played. At initial release, there were a few bugs such as disappearing raft, flying sharks, and low sound quality rain, but those were all fixed very quickly. As of now, the only bugs/glitches I know of are the double/triple paddle and flying with palm trees. Very solid game with few bugs.

[b]Why I Recommend This Game:[/b]

The developers of this game are great, because the game actually gets updates, and said updates [b]actually[/b] add content and fix bugs (looking at you, DayZ). This game has so much potential and with the development roadmap going the way it is, I'd love to see multiplayer co-op and much more content in this game in the future. Keep up the good work, devs!

I've had this game for a long time. I've played this game for a long time. I've pretty much beaten the game as it stands right now and I feel conflicted. This game was beautiful and a load of potential. Sadly, it seems that the developers for some reason updated this game backward from whence it started, most likely due to formatting to console release. I remember when this game had a beautiful life under the water where you could find sunken ships anywhere even in the deepest parts of the water. I also remember when worlds used to be infinite and very fun to explore. Now the oceans lay barren and empty and the world a limited with an out of place yellow floating ball border with nothing but empty ocean after it. I know that the world is limited for reasons of bosses and island creations, but I still can't help but feel that something great was taken away from me. Something that could have grown into something beautiful.
        I bought this game near the moment of this release, and I was really excited, I would even go on to play this game for hours on end. I remember when the community for this game was booming and everyone was excited to see what would come next. And for the most part, we were not disappointed. But there was one thing everyone was begging the developers to implement every sing update they posted. Multiplayer, the thing everyone wanted because no one wanted to survive alone. But as the days, months, and even years grew on, they never added it, but they added plenty of things that people never asked for. Eventually, the community started begging and pleading, but as time went on, so did people. The hype died down and the most abandoned hope. What went from people giving great ideas and sharing love with the game soon became people giving small comments of pity as they clung to what little hope they had left for the game. And while the developers watched their fan-base shrink, they decided to take action, but not to give the people what they want, but to instead bring out a console release. At which point I knew they had given up and decided to run for a cash grab before it was too late.
        The game itself at first is very fun and exciting with plenty of things to look forward to. But after playing long enough you start to realize the grind and just how annoying it is to find the one thing that you need to start doing things that could be actually fun. Like building fun creations. But the building has changed for the worst as they implemented the leveling system that stopped you from building things if you were not high enough level. This leveling system has to be the worst feature I've ever seen in their evolution going backward. The sharks are fun to fight, but they don't even seem to tip over your raft while you sail to another island. Which in my opinion made the game before very challenging in scary. Now sailing to another island is just boring and feels like a waste of time. They also seemed to make the game more complicated as to get the fuel you need to get potatoes, farms, fuel machines, and Jerry Cans. Whereas before you just needed to find a Jerry can with limited fuel already in it. The progression in this game feels more like it's holding you back from experiencing the fun parts until you've experienced the rough buggy hard parts. It took days just to level up enough just so that I could create something that I've wanted through the entire game which I could also acquire in the previous updates just through perseverance and luck.
        Overall this game is dying if not already dead, and though it may seem harsh to say and I may just sound like an old bitter man saying it, I feel that I have been betrayed too many times to have any hope for this game. Though it was fun and I enjoyed myself, I don't think that this game is worth it, it felt like a cash grab in the beginning, and it stayed a cash grab until what looks like the end. This game has betrayed and left it's fans alone for so long to play a game that can only provide so much fun. Is it really too much to ask for one thing? The one thing that everyone wants? I've said it more than once, everyone's said it, but I'll ask one more time...

                                   have fun with my friends and we can all know that you listen.

119523875.review:
Stranded Deep is about as generic a survival game as you can get these days. The overall feel of play-style sways towards simplicity, relying on resource shortage and brutal forward planning in order to hold up the game play mechanic. The world doesn't really feel like it wants to open up to the player, instead opting for a feeling of helplessness and an inevitable grind towards success.

Crafting is, at best, basic and, at its worst, frustrating. Creating a raft (your primary item of choice if you wish to survive) is simple, but also tricky to undertake because of physics collisions, weight distribution problems (placing a single vehicle tyre onto your raft can have the entire construction spinning out of control, or cause it to drown) and space restrictions. It's meant to be realistic, but the execution of it is glitchy and immersion-breaking, often adding frustration to your task. On top of that, there is very little you are allowed to add to the raft as a vehicle, ending up with your final creation being uninspiring and boring. Want to build a little sleep area that's enclosed, with maybe something to cook on - Nope! You can construct a shelf system for your crates, a sail, a rudder, a simple stone anchor and, if you're really feeling fancy, you can build an outboard engine. The latter of which requires a contrived, painfully slow process of farming potatoes (from limited resources) in order to distill them into fuel. It all feels a bit over-the-top., while also being incredibly underwhelming.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2839474907
Crafting on land is marginally more involved, with basic structures that you'd expect from a castaway survival situation. It's not terrible, but it's not particularly inspiring either. With resources being cruelly sparse, requiring plenty of island hopping to support any form of player home settlement, it soon becomes tiring to have to travel vast distances just to get some sticks or enough fiber for crafting [i]and[/i] water production. Some might enjoy the challenge - indeed I did at first - but it soon becomes a grind, taking away the thrill of exploration and discovery and replacing it with necessity. Not really good for anything but die-hard survivalist wannabe's.

As for the story - I honestly haven't come across anything so far that gives me a clue of what I am supposed to do to get home. It might be something added on final release, but as yet it's a big mystery to me. I see hints of what I can craft from the story (4 items) but there's no connection to them in any form so far in my 21 hours of this play-through (Day 32) that I am attempting in July of 2022. Hopefully that will change. People shouldn't have to look up spoiler guides and sift through forums just to find out what they should be doing. Short of that you will likely just float aimlessly around the game world until you bump into something, which could take little time for the bold explorer, or tens of hours for the cautious gamer.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2840476978
Now to the bugs; There's plenty! Physics causing catapulting of trees when cutting them down, physics glitches with your raft, instability issues and (for me) a flickering shadows problem that has existed for 7 years, with no progress made by the developers to fix it. I am not alone with this glitch. It's apparently quite common, especially the further you explore and on the larger islands. It's not the end of the World, but it breaks immersion considerably and is extremely uncomfortable on the eyes,

Visually (aside from technical bugs), the game is very pretty to look at. The water elements are quite beautiful and there's plenty of wildlife to make it feel alive and atmospheric. Colour use is decent, giving a truly tropical feel to the environment. Indeed, graphically it is a great showcase of what modern game engine technology can produce. Especially when it's designed by a fairly small team.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2840476961
My gripes: 
1) [b]Graphical glitches need to be prioritized by the developers.[/b] It's not good to have a screen output that's uncomfortable to look at or that ruins all the hard work that's gone into creating this beautiful environment.
2) [b]The islands are all far too small.[/b] There's too much emphasis on forcing players to island-hop for resources. Encouraging the player to explore can still be achieved without brute force. The island sizes never offer enough space for a player to get comfortable in the game and create something special as a home. It feels like the developers are keen for the player to simply keep moving until the end of the, erm... story?!?
3) [b]The story is too well hidden.[/b] I want at least some direction when I play games. It doesn't need to hold my hand, but zero information just makes it aimless and uncertain. Not a good way to design a story. This needs significant work.
4) [b]The grind - there's too much of it![/b] Making a player hop islands (taking up significant time, depending on distance) just to get a few logs to make planks, or resupply an island of wooden sticks for cooking and crafting, because there's nothing left to cut down on the island the player has decided to settle on, is contrived, boring and grindy. There's no need for this. Look at Green Hell or Subnautica for reference. There's an abundance of resources everywhere (for the most part) but it doesn't lock the player into position. Instead it makes preparation for exploration more enjoyable - heightening the excitement of discovering new places.
5) [b]Challenging survival frustrations.[/b] Staying alive is what this game is all about, but the grind added to make it fit into this genre is bordering on lazy design instead of thoughtful complexity. This is a tricky aspect that I also cover in my likes as well, but needs to be mentioned.
6) [b]Painfully slow game development for what is ultimately a very small game.[/b]

My likes:
1) [b]Gorgeous environmental effort.[/b] The world looks beautiful and the water is realistic feeling and immersive. The developers have done a great job with the overall visual and dynamic environment.
2) [b]Decent sound design.[/b] It sounds nice and there's plenty of atmosphere created around the player from the various audio elements.
3) [b]Fantastic colours.[/b] A truly tropical vibe. A lovely water pallet and a vibrant and inviting overall feel for the world space.
4) [b]Wonderful looking wildlife.[/b] With the exception of over-sized crabs, the overall look and feel of the wildlife is so good you'll likely want to spend time (especially under water) just drinking it in and experiencing the flora and fauna of a tropical dream holiday. It's not at all safe, but it's incredibly immersive. Enough that you don't really need a story if there was more space to explore on land and more emphasis on taking in the wonders of the tropics. Very nice indeed.
5) [b]Enough building for the simple craftsman.[/b] There's quite a selection of things to build, even if the game doesn't balance it well or give it purpose. It's not enough for impressive creativity, but it lends to the game enough to warrant a mention.
6) [b]Challenging survival.[/b] Staying alive is tough. You need to look where you are going and pay attention to your needs. it's what the game centers around and it, almost, works. I prefer thoughtful survival mechanics over brute force, lazy design. It's a bit of "love it and hate it" as far as this aspect goes.

I'd give this game a somewhat generous 7/10, but must warn of glitches that can potentially ruin your experience.

Imagine being stranded on an island in the Pacific after your private jet has crashed without leaving any remnants whatsoever, it has just magically disappeared... What do you do? Spell out SOS or HELP on the beach? Make a signal fire? Find some way to communicate your location to the outside world? Yeah... not in Stranded Deep. 

You build yourself a HELICOPTER of course! Like any random business man (who is somehow also a technological genius with the knowhow to build a chopper) would do. (I would probably prefer a radio, but that's just me) Okay heli built, so you're on your way to safety, right? Wrong! You use it to keep visiting other small islands which pretty much all look the same, are covered in impenetrable bushes, have the same basic materials and are surrounded by shipwrecks with more or less the same loot. That's pretty much all there is to do in the game. 

You CAN build a base... but to be honest there's not really a point in doing that, as you will spend most of your time island hopping. So maybe a floating base or big boat? Ehm... the closest thing available is a raft with a tiny sail (which somehow is powerfull enough to provide enough propulsion) or an outboard motor on it. 
There is no way to secure cargo on board either, so you better hope that nosy shark won't flip your craft (it will...) As you prepare to sail the most shark infested waters you'll ever find, you better pray you don't run into one of them, or get caught in a storm, or get disoriented by the fog rolling in...

[i]“We don't want to work on Stranded Deep forever. If all goes well, we're hoping to have it completed by the end of 2015 (...) Early Access is getting a bad reputation lately and we'd like to help turn that around"[/i] 

More than 3,5 years later that goals seems more than a little ambitious? The game has never been anything other than EA! And even though they have been 'developing' the game all they have managed to do is make the game worse. A shining example as to why you should be careful with ea games! 

[i]"The world is infinitely procedurally-generated and full of different biomes (...) We care about the game and the people who play it."[/i]

If only that was the case. The map is tiny and so are the islands in it, which to make things worse all look pretty much the same too. The vegetation is bland and unimaginative if you compare it to the multitude of fruitbearing trees and plants in the pacific. 

[b]Steer clear of buying this game. The developers are in over their heads, a waste of a really good idea for a game.[/b]

33804015.review:
WARNING: the preview videos and screenshots of this game on the Steam Store page DO NOT accurately reflect it's current state.

I was really excited about Stranded Deep when I first bought it - over a year ago.  While it was rough around the edges and there was very limited content, what was there was cohesive, worked well, and was fun.  Not bad for an early access game.  Lots of promise and there were moments the game was genuinely beautiful!

HOWEVER.

Since then, while updates have been vaguely regular, they are EXTREMELY thin in terms of new content or feature progress, and most of the time they REMOVE something that was working well and put something new in its place that is broken, half-finished, and just plain not fun to use.  Since I bought the game, they have:
- Made it all but impossible to see more than 10 feet underwater, making it basically useless to try and dive because sharks will kill you in the blink of an eye and you can't see them coming - and yet sharks actively home in on you the moment you get in the water
- Replaced a good crafting interface with a clunky and slow one that has performance issues
- Messed with resource generation and scarcity on the starting island, breaking the early gameplay resource usage and needs curves
- Made the islands VASTLY SMALLER
- Removed a variety of crucial tools that were simple and effective and instead put confusing multi-part crafting solutions in their place that aren't even working right and are grindy and not fun
- Added and removed content seemingly at random with no clear plan or roadmap to a final content set
- Repeatedly released buggy updates that need a hotfix to solve a gamebreaking bug within the first few days

I make games for a living.  I've worked on PC and Xbox games from large to small, and I know what rookie teams and experienced teams look like based on how they handle development.  What I am seeing here is an extremely small team (not a crime) that is in waaaay over their head (not a crime, but also not a good thing) and doesn't realize it (bad), and who is utterly failing to communicate effectively with their player base (uh oh).  They are not upfront about what they can do and when they're likely to get it done, or their plans to make it happen, because there's no clear sign they actually know any of those things (EJECT).

The development arc of this game has headed badly downhill since I bought it and I would not have purchased it if I knew it would be in its current state after more than a year.  I cannot recommend others buy it.  Until Beam Team can figure out how to communicate what they're doing, how they plan to do it, prove they actually know how, and show some steady progress along that plan, then as far as I can tell you'll just be shelling out for their broken, slowly meandering tinkering project that is never done and always tearing up what it just finished.

What a disappointment.

14336905.review:
This game is the best early-access I've ever played, If you're into survival, exploration, and crafting : GET THIS GAME!
It's a very good bargain. The fact that this small Indie a team has a faster, better and friendlier response to its players than other Early-Access games *cough* dayz *cough* should be enough to convince you to buy this, because it means your money did not go to waste, as these devs will fix and solve the bugs you actually post.

But enough about the devs, lets talk about the game!

The intro to the game is pretty generic to survival games (crashing off a plane) but at least you get to make your own martini before descending into your doom. It is also very well made, the intro looks realistic and its not just some stupid black screen at the end of it. 

Afterwards you wake up on the raft you climbed on before being blown to sh1t with your trusty paddle and you will find a tiny island : your new home.

There you can gather resources and craft new items and tools necessary for your survival. The crafting in this game is very original, and you will not be disappointed. Instead of depending on a generic crafting screen, this game actually handles that in the physical game world, meaning you have to lay down some sticks, rope and rock before you before you can start crafting your spear.

You have the ability to hunt crabs (easiest) or fish from the ocean, even bigger fish near the reefs and deeper into the water. Hell, if you're brave enough you can actually chase that stupid shark thats been circling your beloved raft for so long, and kill it, and COOK IT! As of now you cant eat shark fin soup, but you can still eat the fin, and other parts.

The cooking is quite realistic, you will have to wait a while before your crabs become crispy and tasty, instead of insta-cooking.

You will have to manage your resources as they are quite finite, which after a while will force you to navigate to other islands in search for more wood and rocks. Especially if you want to build a nice big hut. 

This game has a few bugs, but none of them are game-breaking which is something very worth your money these days.

The main reason why I think you should get this game is because it has so damn much potential. And when all the amazing new features start coming in you will start to realize how you should have bought this game early on, you can wait, sure. But you'll miss out on alot of fun. It is always nice to support such a promising game. Even more when you've got community friendly devs, and amazing gameplay.

50/10 - would live off crabs and coconuts again

31072837.review:
I remember an experience I had playing this game shortly after it was released. I was on my raft heading back to a secondary base island after scavenging for resources from one of the far-off islands, a necessary errand since single islands didn't provide many resources and your backpack could only hold 8 things at a time. These were long journeys (~10-15 minutes) and required some intelligent resource managing to make it there and back in good health but with enough new materials to make the trip worthwhile. I began the trip in the evening and soon realized I had made a mistake when heavy rain began pouring down. To allow more backpack room I didn't bring my compass, so with my visilibity reduced to mere feet in front of me I did my best to maintain my direction of rowing. I was feeling pretty confident until the music began that indicates the proximity of a shark, and my heart began to race. Sure enough I saw a dark shadow in the water below me, circling around my raft and making occasional attempts to bump it over.  In short order I became disoriented and realized I had forgotten in which direction I had been travelling. My first thought was, my island was a tiny dot on the horizon, and the chances of me missing it are pretty high; I could try staying stationary and wait out the rain so I can regain my bearings, but the thought of being on top of a bottomless pit of giant monsters convinced me to redouble my navigational efforts and strike out in the most likely direction (which, very fortunately, were just barely correct enough and I eventually reached my intended island). My second thought was, holy shit, this game has absolutely nailed the terror and challenge of this sort of nightmare scenario in a way no other game I've played has.

The reason why I don't recommend it is because in the years since then, rather than expanding on what made the game so unique, the developments have done nothing but bring the game half-way up to par with the survival genre generic standards, drowning its strengths in the cesspool of bloated crafting systems and meaningless item-scavenging that characterizes nearly every other survival game on the market. Instead of adding more ways to challenge resource-management and survival skills, or adding more risk-reward events and mechanics, there are simply more ways to build your house and hoard all the rocks and branches you can find, and more ways to blow up sharks.

It still has a lot of potential, but the developers don't seem to know what it is.

80502648.review:
Survival games are the Marmite genre in the gaming industry. 
Ironically, if you happen to be in the love camp, you’ll no doubt end up loathing the game as its brutal ways end your life and game prematurely. 
It’s an extremely challenging genre which will make you scream with frustration, while still compelling you to keep playing. 
Have you ever wondered what it was like for Tom Hanks in Castaway? 
Living each day as it comes, learning survival skills as you go along, and scrabbling around for items to make a shelter, and food to survive? Well, wonder no more. 

Stranded Deep where you explore an open world, trying to fight the elements while staying alive. 
There was always the promise of a storyline, and more in depth gameplay. 
This has allowed me to sit here and review it for you.

The action starts with a rather calm setting. 
You sit in a private jet on a flight to some unknown destination, for some unspecified reason. 
This peace is very quickly disturbed when the shrill alarms sound from the cockpit. 
A sudden shudder, and you are free falling through the air. 
Sections of the body are ripped from the fuselage, followed by the inevitable crash landing into the sea. 
You somehow exit the wreck and must make it to a life raft, from here your adventure begins.

As the cutscene ends, you are given full control. 
You are now introduced to basic gameplay mechanics in the form of a short tutorial, this explains how to gather and craft, how to use your watch to observe your stats, and the importance of building a shelter so that you can save your data. 
Once the tutorial is complete you are on your own. 
Afforded the freedom to explore your first little island, and the world around you. 
There really is a lot to see and do; you must hunt animals, farm or scavenge off the land for food and water supplies. 
Use your raft, or build a new vessel to cross the open waters. 
Find new islands to call home, explore shipwrecks in the depths of the ocean, and clamber across the decks of marooned tankers to search for vital clues to help find a way home.

Whatever task you decide to undertake, you must plan and consider the benefits against the negatives. 
Nearly every action is fraught with danger, you must stay alert in order to ensure you can live another day. 
Snakes, sharks, poisonous coral, heat, UV, starvation, dehydration, and many more pitfalls will welcome you on your journey. For every negative, there is an action you can complete to overcome it. 
You can craft weapons to fight, Antivenom to overcome poisons, a shelter can be made to hide from the sun, and water collectors and cooking areas will keep you topped up on your vital statistics. 
These things are all good while you are at home, but when you go exploring you must be prepared. 
Do not run before you can walk.

The wondrous thing about Stranded Deep is the freedom to choose whether you live in this dangerous open world for as long as your heart desires, while luck is on your side, or you attempt to complete the story mode.
If you do try to escape your new life, don’t expect to be given clues as to how to achieve this, you must discover the solution for yourself. 
This lack of direction will not be to everyone’s liking.
The true hardcore fan will love the challenge of pitting their wits against a harsh and ever changing environment, which has considerably more hazards than it does safe areas. 
The learning curve is almost unforgiving, so expect to die an awful lot when first starting out. 
Once you understand the basic fundamentals, you should still expect to perish just as much. 
You’ll soon learn that the save facility is your best friend. There is nothing more frustrating than being poisoned halfway through a run through, with no Antivenom. 
You either panic and search like a crazy person for the much needed medication, or you resign yourself to the fact that this is another save that didn’t get you to the end game.

Character progression is achieved by completing any given task. Hack down a load of palm trees, and your harvesting skill increases. 
Smash a crab with a rock, you’ll be a better hunter, and so on and so forth, you get the point. A
ction equals reward. Better stats ultimately make the game easier, by reducing the time it takes to finish a job. 
However, this isn’t the only way to make your experience much simpler. 
You start out with rudimentary tools, these are made from sticks and stones. 
As your skill improves, you can craft better items as long as you have the correct resources. 
Searching shipwrecks and Islands will occasionally unearth chests. 
Inside these will potentially be rare resources or advanced equipment. 
You discover that everything has a limited durability. 
Everything breaks eventually, and if your luck is like mine, it usually happens when you are attacking a predator, this leaves you powerless to overcome any attack.

Stranded Deep utilises both a day and night cycle, and varying weather fronts. 
As the light changes, the shadows work perfectly in creating a sense of realism. 
The night darkness really keeps you on edge. Why not make a torch? 
I hear you say! If only it was that easy to come across cloth in the early game!
Your only choices are; walk by the light of the moon, or cower by your campfire.
The howling wind and driving rain looks prefect, the trees sway and the rain hammers down on the water and sand.
Only the brave and stupid venture into the waters in a storm. 
I won’t ruin the surprise for you, but needless to say, rafts and waves is not an experience I’m willing to go through again in a hurry. 
For the most part the game looks fantastic, the variety of hot and cold colours transport you to the tropical lands, the sea looks cool and refreshing, and the animal animations are smooth. 
Snakes are renowned for being experts at camouflage, they are practically invisible. 

As you come to expect with a game in this genre, there really is a lot to do. 
Once you are familiar with the control system the action plays out very nicely. 
The response rate is very good, and a number of shortcuts have been implemented to help with in game tasks, including being able to pin crafting recipes to the screen to help with gathering resources.

One of a few title’s that I have reviewed, where I’m barely scratching the surface of what can be done, and how much I can explore. 
This title is vast, with plenty to make you want to return. 
If you feel that the designed world gets tedious, then you can create a whole new procedurally generated one to explore. 
You have the ability to alter the difficulty, and remove the main predators all together. 
There is a leaderboard to compete with friends, and a plethora of easy and difficult achievements to aim for. 
As already mentioned, you can spend your whole time surviving and building yourself a home, or you can push to try and escape. 
All these options make the replay factor of this game incredible. 
I honestly feel the only thing that will prevent you from wanting to keep playing, is the brutal difficulty level. 
I found it quite disheartening, until I decided I wanted back in again.

The way the action plays out, and the graphical presentation makes this an extremely immersive title. 
I opened by saying that the survival genre is like Marmite. 
You either love it, or hate it.
I think that Stranded Deep will emphasise this fact.
This is one unbelievably in depth game that will push its fan base to its limits. 
With the options to live out your Tom Hanks, and Bear Grylls dreams indefinitely, this is one that will ensure that you spend many hours trying to ensure that you survive your isolation.
Great value for money, and something that I’d certainly recommend. 
Grab yourself a volleyball, paint a hand on it, and keep it with you.
 Your “Wilson” may be the only friend that will help to keep you sane is this lonely existence.

32308208.review:
*UPDATE*

A year later I decided to give this another shot. Somehow it is actually worse. I could not figure out how to cook sardines. I'm not stupid.. this game is just crap. It's really that simple. It remains pretty as ever visually, but with a crafting system that is frankly just idiotic. Daft decisions like the inability to burn planks remain. I give up - it's clear the designers don't care.

*ORIGINAL from June, 2017*

I really wanted to like this game but ultimately it's just not that fun, though I'd say it does deliver in terms of what it promises.

What I like:
* Graphics are pretty good, it does feel like you're on an island; it's reasonably pretty
* Great music.. really adds to the mood
* Controls are fairly intuitive, though there are some things you'll inevitably look up - like how to smoke fish.

What I don't:
* Crafting that makes no sense.. I can have a tinroofing floor for a raft but not.. a roof? 
* Absurd durability.. machetes fall apart quickly but stone tools are invincible?
* More advanced tools don't work much better than primitive tools.
* Inventory system scales poorly.. lockers need to carry more stuff
* Inability to get a lot of use out of furniture
* Structures that are silly like having to build multiple fire pits if you want a smoker AND a spit AND a regular fire.. etc..
* Did I mention the crafting system makes no sense? Why is drift wood and regular wood different? Why can't I deconstruct things? Like a crate into planks.. or a raft into a tarp + rope.
* Too much dependence on wood.
* Not a lot of opportunities to harvest things from the environment.. there's almost no point in going underwater.

Ultimately there simply isn't much to do.. You build a house.. and.. then what? A raft.. so you can go to another island that doesn't have your house? I just don't really see the point I guess. I think the game would be much better if rather than having to island hop between tiny irrelevant islands you instead washed ashore on a tiny island nearer a larger one.. and had to make your way there and then explore it. That would at least give you something to do.

Also unless I went swimming, I never really felt in danger. Once you build a couple solar stills water is not an issue. Sleep is easy.. and food isn't too difficult.  Getting food and water turns into more of a chore than a struggle. Wristwatch says I need to drink? Okay let me head over to my still and top up.  I'm not really sure what I'd suggest to improve this. I feel like it's very hard to convey in a game, the thrill and satisfaction of eating when you're very hungry.
